abstract: The markets are global, but the decision-making isn’t. Therein lies the danger that transcends borders.

lead_paragraph: JUST before JPMorgan Chase announced its initial $2-a-share deal to buy Bear Stearns, Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, held an extraordinary impromptu conference call. The participants on the Sunday night call, who got a preview of the deal, were Wall Street’s biggest power brokers: Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs dialed in from home. John Mack of Morgan Stanley rushed to the office to listen on speakerphone. Richard Fuld of Lehman Brothers, who had been directed to return home from a business trip in New Delhi by none other than Henry Paulson, the Treasury secretary, was patched in, too, among others.

abstract: The Federal Reserve Board on Tuesday formally gave its approval to JPMorgan Chase to purchase a banking unit of Bear Stearns.

abstract: The Federal Reserve has drawn lots of questions about its role in arranging last month’s fire sale of Bear Stearns to JPMorgan Chase. On Wednesday, lawmakers got their first chance to ask the Fed’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, about the Fed’s decision to invoke a rule not used since the 1930s to act as financial midwife to the hastily brokered deal.
